The 'great' Shaikh Sultan bin Saqr of Sharjah before his death in 1866 divided his country amongst his four sons as follows: Salim - Ras al Khaimah. Majid - Kalba. Ahmad - Diba. Khalid Sharjah. Ras al Khaimah has from time to time been recognised by H.M.G. as independent of Sharjah and consistently so since 1921. Diba has never been recognised as independent but has been regarded as part of Kalba since that Sheikhdom became independent. 2. Kalba though in fact more or less independent of Sharjah f° r many years was never recognised as such until 193& when we required certain facilities for aircraft there. The Ruler of Sharjah was unable to obtain these for us and accordingly on the 28th August, 1936 we recognised Shaikh Sa’id, the grandson of Majid, as independent and entered into treaty relations with him. We also on the same day entered into an agreement with him for providing facilities for aircraft at Kalba'. This agreement expired in 1948 and has not been renewed. 3a id died in an his minor son Hamad was accepted by the people of Kalba as his successor. They subsequently accepted Khalid bin Ahmad as Regent during his minority. Hamad on attaining his majority took over as Ruler in 1950 and on the 5th July, 1951 was murdered by Saqr bin Sultan bin Salim of the Ras al Khaimah branch of the family. It is believed that with the murder of Hamad the Kalba branch of the family has become extinct in the male line. 3. In 1928 Petroleum Concessions Limited (now Petroleum Development (Trucial Coast.)) obtained a concession from the Regent of Kalba under which they paid him Rs. 24,000 annually. While Hamad was Ruler they paid to him Rs. 3»5pO per quarter and as a result of an agreement which he signed, of A , , Rs. 2,500 as a sort of pension to the ex-Regent Khalid bin Ahmad. Since Hamad* s death the quarterly payment to the Ruler has been suspended and the money kept in deposit in the bank, but the payment to Khalid has continued.^t/i ' t'.'93/53. In the primitive conditions prevailing in Kalba I am inclined to think that any money of Hamad’s must be regarded as his personal property and not that of the State. In such circumstances we have, strictly speaking, no jurisdiction over it and it could only be paid out on the basis of an order by a competent Shar’a Court. I do not know if there is a Qadhi at Kalba but, even if there is, in the present circumstances it is unlikely that we could obtain an impartial decree from him. I am therefore of opinion that all money in the bank due to Hamad should be held there pending further developments, and Vilton may be instructed to advise the bank accordingly. In any case it would no^, I imagine, pay the money out except under the direction of a competent Court or of the Political Officer. (W.R. Hay) W. S. Dear Sir Rupert, I appreciate the difficulty in finding a suitable successor to the late Shaikh Hamad of Kalba, explained in your letter Nol 10112/42 of the 30th October. 2. When Saqr bin Sultan is finally evicted however it will be essential to show the other Trucial Coast Shaikhs, as well as the people of Kalba, that murder and unlawful usurpation of thrones are utterly opposed to the prinpiples which we consider should prevail throughout the States. 3. You have suggested Sultan bin Salim as a possible Ruler in place of his usurper son Saqr. In view of the wholly discreditable past history of the Sultan as well as the fact that he is so closely related to Sqqr, his recognition would not, I feel, impress the other Shaikhs sufficiently with the extent to which we condemn the crime and the method of its perpetration. &. I should be glad to know therefore the result of the consultations with other members of the Jawasim family which Wilton is to have and also any further suggestions which you may have as regards other possible successors. If Sultan bin Salim remains the only possible person I should like to give further consideration to the case here before any action is taken towards recognising him as Ruler since I am doubtful whether we could approve such a proposal. 5 . I am anxious that Saqr should not be allowed to remain too long in Kalba and I agree with your directions in paragraph 2 of your letter to Laver No. 10112/4.1 of 30th October, that the strongest possible pressure should be brought to bear on him and that a more forceful course of action should now be planned. Yours sincerely, R«P.§. garell. for (G.W. Furlonge) Lieutanant Colonel Sir Rupert Hay, K. C. I.E., C. S. I., Bahrain. j

mods.abstract: The file comprises correspondence relating to discussion amongst British officials over the fate of the Sheikhdom of Kalba in the wake of the assassination of its ruler, Ḥamad bin Sa’id Āl Qāsimī. The file is a direct chronological continuation of ‘File 22/6 I Kalba’ (IOR/R/15/2/941). The principal correspondents in the file are: the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf (Lieutenant-Colonel William Rupert Hay); the Political Agent at Bahrain (William Scott Laver); and the British Agent at Sharjah, also referred to as the Political Officer on the Trucial Coast (Arthur John Wilton).Correspondence includes: Wilton’s description of the negotiations taking place amongst the Jawasim [Āl Qāsimī] in Sharjah, over whether Sultain bin Salim should be installed as Ruler of Kalba (ff 12-15), a decision which Foreign Office officials are doubtful that they could approve (f 19); Hay’s proposals to allow Kalba to revert to Sharjah, in light of the fact that the deceased ruler, Ḥamad bin Sa’id, had no legitimate heirs (f 18); Hay’s note on the Sheikhdom of Kalba, dated 26 November 1951 (f 10). Correspondence also refers to the continued concession payments being made by Petroleum Concessions Limited (PCL) to Sheikh Khalid bin Aḥmad Āl Qāsimī, former Regent of Kalba, and proposals to blockade Wadi al Quar [Khawr] as a means of removing Saqr bin Sultan bin Salim from Kalba (ff 16-17).The first item of correspondence in the file is not directly related to the Kalba negotiations: a letter from J Gethin of the British Consulate in Muscat, to the Political Resident, dated 10 December 1951, informing the Resident that the ruler of Kalba has moved the aperture in the frontier wall separating Kalba from Oman (f 3).
